Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Microbial friends and foes: towards a synthesis of interspecific interactions
Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites award has been made to Cornell University that will provide research training for 10 students, for 10 weeks during the summers of 2014-2016. The program focuses on host-microbe interactions. It will train undergraduate students in the concepts, research questions, and experimental approaches central to understanding microbial interactions with eukaryotic hosts. The Department of Plant Pathology & Plant-Microbe Biology (PPPMB) has about 40 faculty who will serve as mentors. A common theme among research programs in PPPMB is species interactions, both mutualistic and antagonistic. REU participants will learn about broad diversity of microbe-eukaryote interactions through full-time research, lab meetings, weekly seminars, and group discussions. Strong emphasis will be placed on teaching scientific method and strategies for conducting research, and on the synthesis of concepts of interspecific interactions across diverse systems. Students will also participate in workshops devoted to research ethics, electronic database literacy, science citation software, science communication, planning for graduate study, including attention to personal statements and resumes, and GRE preparation. REU students will have access to a rich array of individual mentor's facilities as well as the Cornell University Life Sciences Core Laboratories focused on genomics, proteomics and mass spectrometry, microscopy and imaging as well as bioinformatics and computational biology. The program's multi-phase recruitment effort consists of both traditional "hard copy" formats as well as digital-based advertising. Undergraduates from groups underrepresented in science are encouraged to apply. Participants are selected based on academic record, research performance, and potential for outstanding research in biology. Students are tracked to determine their continued interest in their academic field of study, their career paths, and the lasting influences of the research experience. Information about the program will be assessed by various means, including use of an REU common assessment tool available to BIO-funded REU PIs. More information is available by visiting reu.pppmb.cornell.edu, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Teresa Pawlowska at tep8@cornell.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Michael Milgroom at mgm5@cornell.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The overall scientific goal of the Microbial Friends & Foes (MFF) REU Summer Site, associated with the Plant Pathology and Plant-Microbe Biology Section (PPPMB) of the School of Integrative Plant Science (SIPS) at Cornell University, was to train undergraduate students in the concepts, research questions, and experimental approaches central to understanding microbial interactions with eukaryotic hosts. Over the course of three years, 20 research programs representing PPPMB and the Microbiology Department hosted 35 students. MFF student research projects were devoted to various aspects of microbial interactions with eukaryotic hosts, including evolutionary dynamics, ecological determinants, and molecular mechanisms. Within the first week of the program, each student prepared a brief research proposal reviewed by the program PIs. To make sure that all students were equally prepared for research activities, the MFF program included sessions on The Scientific Method, How to Read Scientific Literature, and Scientific Database Searching and Citation Management.  MFF students participated in a campus-wide annual Symposium on Ethics in Science organized by the Cornell University Office of Undergraduate Biology (OUB). To complement research activities, students were involved in weekly Synthesis Panels in which they discussed research projects, identified overarching conceptual themes and synthesized them in group presentations. Each year, faculty hosts developed and presented a series of 8 lectures devoted to Theoretical and Practical Aspects of Host-Microbe Biology. A Workshop in R Programming was offered annually to MFF participants and mentors by a graduate student from one of the host labs. At the conclusion of the program, REU students reported their research findings in both poster and oral presentations. Poster sessions gathered MFF program participants, their mentors as well as PPPMB and Microbiology personnel. Oral presentations were part of the Summer Institute for Life Sciences Symposium, an annual campus-wide event organized by the Cornell OUB. Results of four MFF projects were either submitted (Mondo et al. 2016; Vargas-Asencio et al. 2017) or are being prepared (Lastovetsky et al. 2017a; Lastovetsky et al. 2017b) for publication with REU students as co-authors.

Broader Impacts of the Work. Broader impact goals of the MFF REU program were to: (1) involve Biology undergraduates from groups underrepresented in science, (2) prepare students to apply to graduate school and advance their careers in science, (3) train students in how to conduct research, acquire technical skills for research, and explore biology more deeply by being engaged in research. To address these goals, the MFF REU was advertised through: (1) mailing fliers to ~ 500 life science departments in colleges across the country, including minority-serving institutions, (2) participation and flier distribution at minority educational conferences MANRRS (2014) and SACNAS (2015), and (3) a program website http://reu.pppmb.cals.cornell.edu/.

Between 65 and 100 applications were received each year. Applications were reviewed by the two co-PIs. Preference was given to students representing: (1) minorities underrepresented in science and (2) colleges with limited opportunities to conduct research. Bundles of 3-7 preselected applications were presented to faculty hosts for final selection. Over the three years of the MFF program, among the 35 participants, 26 represented non-Ph.D.-granting institutions, 24 were females, five Hispanic, two African American, one Native American and one Pacific Islander.

Professional development activities offered annually by the MFF program included: (1) a Graduate School Luncheon, organized in collaboration with the Plant Genome Research Program at the Boyce Thompson Institute, featuring presentations by Directors of Graduate Studies in various life science disciplines at Cornell, (2) a Graduate Student Panel bringing together MFF participants and current PPPMB and Microbiology graduate students for a session of graduate school-related questions and answers, and (3) a Summer SIPS Picnic aimed at facilitating social interactions and networking of REU students with life science faculty. Lastly, housing MFF students in on-campus residence halls allowed them to network with participants of summer programs in other disciplines.

Of the 20 MFF participants from Summer 2014 and Summer 2015, two could not be contacted to enquire about their career paths, four remain in college, one transferred from a community college to a 4-year institution, two are taking a gap year before applying to graduate school, four are pursuing medical careers, and seven were accepted to Ph.D. programs. Many of these decisions were motivated by participation in the MFF program.
